content: Brainstorm ideas for how to scale :)
One other thing I will say is that we can do more than one thing, if other folks want to lead. Anybody can create a google meet :)

I'm wondering if this could be recorded and then posted to something like YouTube, if the code reading club were to be restricted to a small, well vetted group of participants (say 5 ish), who are comfortable enough with being recorded?
Subset of people pre-read and generate questions
That is, I'm still interested in pursuing a more "intimate" setting, but that's not exclusive with also considering streamed formats and the like.
then experts answer them in a broadcast as part of a presentation format.
(i.e., try to move to an async model)
By "intimate" do you mean people you know or a small number of people?

I personally feel that a streaming Q&A is the best option while the number of active participants is over 100, but once there are regularly less than 100 participants (which I am certain will be the case after a few weeks), then it can be moved to zoom.
I'll add myself to those who would love to see a streaming Q&A, with a few experts on one part of the compiler answering questions from the chat, while everyone is reading together

One thing I'm interested in, I don't know a lot about the topics that would be discussed, but I am capable of leading a group of people through the code reading activities. Would a group of facilitators be able to lead smaller sections without the experience? Or do facilitators need to know the topic quite well?
um
a serious idea:

Brian Merchant said:

I'm wondering if this could be recorded and then posted to something like YouTube, if the code reading club were to be restricted to a small, well vetted group of participants (say 5 ish), who are comfortable enough with being recorded?

I do also like this idea, except I wonder if this would also be better done as a stream (rather than a recording), so that the "observer" questions get answered if the "active participants" don't ask those questions.
maybe we should just do it on zulip?
through chat?
right
scales infinitely high :)
zulip sounds pretty good to me tbh
https://hackmd.io/@rustc-reading-club/S1xsDveDK#/ <-- that was going to be our slides, but I don't know how much sense they'll make

I'm interested in something closer in format to a compiler team meeting (with participants limited to team(s) members and contributors, ~10-15 participants in a single meeting), so people have some familiarity with the compiler, can all participate actively, and the meeting is not drowned in explaining basics.

This format can be parallel to what the rustc-reading-club turned out to be in practice - a public event with >100 observers.
yes, I think that if we're going to have >100 people, it makes sense to have smaller sessions

Would you guys be willing to stream/record a meeting like that? (No is a totally fair answer :sweat_smile: )

I think a lot of the interest (speaking for myself here) is people who don't have familiarity with the compiler and need explanations of the basics - but would like to contribute back to rustc, given some support and an entrypoint to start.

nikomatsakis said:

maybe we should just do it on zulip?

From Katja in the zoom call, this is how they handled when they had 80+ participants. Katja also mentioned that they would be willing to "onboard" different facilitators to potentially help if the direction goes towards many different rooms in a Zoom/Jitsi/... call

Maybe the reading club could be parallelized: match up groups of ~10 people without a designated facilitator and provide written instructions/guidelines on how to self-conduct the meeting. Experts then could occasionally join different groups to answer questions that might have come up reading the code.

Vadim Petrochenkov said:

I'm interested in something closer in format to a compiler team meeting (with participants limited to team(s) members and contributors, ~10-15 participants in a single meeting), so people have some familiarity with the compiler, can all participate actively, and the meeting is not drowned in explaining basics.

This format can be parallel to what the rustc-reading-club turned out to be in practice - a public event with >100 observers.

For me the reading group seemed like a very nice opportunity to learn about rustc with the intention of learning how to contribute, so I'd be somewhat sad if this closed format ended up being adopted.

It seems the idea going forward is to have multiple sessions in parallel. It might be an idea to ask people about their rough familiarity with rustc, so you can group those that are familiar together, separate from those that need to dwell on the basics a bit more.

Alex Keizer said:

It seems the idea going forward is to have multiple sessions in parallel. It might be an idea to ask people about their rough familiarity with rustc, so you can group those that are familiar together, separate from those that need to dwell on the basics a bit more.

I would actually disagree here. It makes more sense to split groups into a good mix of "familiar" and "not familiar" people
I think having familiar people mixed in with not familar makes sense, if the familiar people understand their role in that meeting
but that doesn’t exclude the potential utility of having a separate meeting of people who are all famiilar with the code base.

pnkfelix said:

I think having familiar people mixed in with not familar makes sense, if the familiar people understand their role in that meeting

My experience with attending our namesake, the code reading club, is that more experienced people get value from the questions that people who are learning offer. As it pertains to rustc, it is possible that the questions, suggestions or struggles of people new to the codebase could influence future development as the current contributors gain insight into how people are approaching and understanding the choices they've made.

pnkfelix said:

I think having familiar people mixed in with not familiar makes sense, if the familiar people understand their role in that meeting

There is definitely value for both familiar and less familiar sharing their thoughts and insights while reading code together.

breakout rooms? discussed this with @Doc Jones over discord, and Doc had some very valid concerns (who would lead?, how would we synchronize breakouts?) but just tossing this in the mix just in case :)

i think just being around people who are interested in learning more about rustc could lead to a productive convo no matter whether they were synced up. but I also don’t know a whole lot about how code reading clubs usually function :)

@Chaz Kiker If you read all the suggests above, you will find that breakout rooms have been mentioned. :)

As for gatherings of people who want to discuss rustc, I'm all for it! Would you like to volunteer to set one up? I support the idea 100%. We can do more than one thing. Someone mentioned doing a twitch stream on developing for rustc and rustdoc, and to that idea I say yes! What is clear, as Niko said earlier today, the amazing response we saw for the first rustc reading club shows that there was an unmet need uncovered today. We, as a community, should do all the things.

More is more, in this case.
